content.description: A great sport route, much fun to be had. Starts in a chimney (it's easier then it 1st appears) and one side-clips the 1st bolt leaning out from the right. The climbing then goes directly above 1 (it's not necessary to go out right). The crux follows off 2 and features an extremely challenging clip to 3 (might have been at one time much easier and for this reason we took off a star); this section is the lowest angle part of the climb but is very bouldery. The upper part of the climb is amusing large holds which somewhat helps if you are tall. The last bolt intelligently directs the rope from not abrading against the face below. The anchor is on the right.
content.location: The central part of the wall in the dihedral.

content.description: The Last Gentleman climbs the striking arete on the Hook Wall. This climb demands the attention of any climber who seeks aesthetically pleasing lines. Start on the crimp rail that traverses left to the arete. Then, manage your way up, styling, movin' and groovin' to the anchors. This one will be sure to leave you smiling.
content.location: The obvious arete that can be seen from afar.

climbs.name: The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly
climbs.fa: Marty Karabin and Harvey Delos Reyes

content.description: This route has a crux between the 1st two bolts. It consists of extremely painful monos. It's followed by easy climbing to the anchors. The bad and grungy weren't so terribly bad and grungy, however, the "good" at the start...was baadd.
content.location: This is located two (2) routes over from the large dihedral in the center of the wall.
First bolted route right of chimney corner.

content.description: This wall is basically an extension of the Lost Boys wall to its west. Also, although the wall faces south, the large-ish arete in the center blocks late day sun.
